div1.p: Laura Armistead Carter transcribes a conversation between Henry Rose Carter, Thayer, and Parker, which shows how Carter's data on extrinsic incubation assisted Lazear and Reed in reaching the decision to test the theory of mosquito transmission. Carter also discusses the contributions of Finlay and others to this theory.

div1.head: Article, by Laura Armistead Carter, July, 1924 [Enclosed in C0312017]

Tells of her Fathers talk with

& of his own paper on extrinsic incubation
of yellow fever. (over)

Part of a talk between Drs. Carter, Thayer & Parker
on Sunday afternoon, July 19141924, transcribed
from short-hand notes taken at the time.
Carter: “Lazear was the first one to whom I showed
my piece.” (on extrinsic incubation) “That was before
Reed came down. It was abominably printed, with
the tables strung out in a straight line, & I had to
have an extra leaf typed & stuck in, to make them
clear, after he had read it he said: ‘If these dates are
correct, if spells a living host’. ‘possibly’ I replied ‘there
are however 3 conceivable explanations for it’, & I told
him of the conclusion of my original article, of
which they were the summary, but which Geddings
had advised me to omit from the printed piece,
for fear that they might detract from the simple
acceptance of the data. I said:

1. It may be the passage through an insect host,
analogous to the passage through the tick in
Texas cattle fever. I had not get heard of Ross's
work on malaria.

2d It may be a change in development, as if it
were eliminated as a spore & vice-versa. I know

Carter continuing: “Lazear was much impressed
& asked me to write it out for him. I had taken
the original MSS. to Cuba with me & next day
I dictated it to his man.

“I did not see Lazear for some time afterward
when Reed came down in June, I met him in
the quarantine launch, put him through
customs & gave him breakfast. I also gave him
a copy of my article.

“I saw Reed again on the 4th of July.

Three of us went out to call on him. When he
came in I saw that he had Lazear's reprit of
my article in his hand, to which the memo-
randum I had written, at his request, was attached.

‘Carter’, he asked, ‘can you swear to y'r figures’?
‘Better than that’ I replied, ‘I can bet on them!’
‘Then’, said he, ‘if that is so, it spells an insect host!’
‘not necessarily’ I said, ‘have you read the memoran-
dom I gave Lazear?’

“He did not answer, owing to some interruption, but
he still held the reprint & memorandum in his
hand.

“I then asked Reed, ‘you know what Finlay says
about it being conveyed by mosquitoes?’

‘Don't tell me!’ he replied. ‘I want to keep a perfectly
unbiased mind on the matter.’

‘Ah! ha! Doctor!’ said Carroll to me, ‘how can
that be possible, since ‘it’ (yellow fever)'s conveyed
by bedding & clothing used about the sick?’

“I said: “It is generally so admitted, but not
universally. I for one do not believe it is I told
him why. (Large amount of bedding & clothing brought
from Havana to New York, during a period of years
in which there was yellow fever in the former, without
yellow fever developing in the latter among the non-
immune maids & other non-immune personel, by
whom it was either unpacked, or who were brought
in contact with it. Didn't get this verbatim, as Father's
pillow slipped, & I had to get up to fix it, L.A.C.
Carter continuing: “Reed said then that Sternberg
had advised him to begin his investigations
with the intestinal flora of those dying of yellow
fever, & that he had intended so doing, but some
time after this the experiments with mosquitoes
were began, I carrying the first of Finlay's
